data.title: Explore the best things to do in Szekesfehervar in one day
data.meta_description: Best things to do in Szekesfehervar! Our guide leads you through the best things to do and inspiring places to explore in Szekesfehervar in one day.
data.text:
Szekesfehervar is a lesser known city in Hungary. Not as popular as some of the other destinations, but well worth the visit. Keep scrolling to find out all about the best things to do in Szekesfehervar, and of course, our favourite attraction.

Put on your walking shoes and enjoy a hearty breakfast because this vibrant city has so much to offer! From the impressive Bory Castle, a testament to passion and creativity, to the charming cobblestone streets lined with centuries-old buildings, every corner of Szekesfehervar is bursting with life and history. Get ready to explore. A day in Szekesfehervar is time well spent, I promise!

During a one-day visit, you can expect to see all thethe important sights in Szekesfehervar. For us, the main attraction of this centrally located town, was Bory Castle, so keep scrolling to find out more!

As the morning mist lifts, Szekesfehervar greets you with a refreshing embrace. The sun casts a warm, golden glow on the city’s ancient facades, sparking an irresistible urge to explore. The morning air is filled with the inviting aroma of freshly brewed coffee from local cafés, subtly nudging you to start your day with a rich Hungarian brew. The city’s heartbeat is palpable as locals start their day, each street and square brimming with an energy that’s uniquely Szekesfehervar. It’s a morning unlike any other, setting the perfect tone for a day of adventure and discovery. So, let’s hit the ground running and make the most out of this vibrant morning in Szekesfehervar!

Step into the King St. Stephen Museum in Székesfehérvár, Hungary, and prepare to be captivated by its rich history and fascinating exhibits. As you explore this renowned museum, you’ll find yourself immersed in a treasure trove of anthropological and stone collections, making it the largest museum of its kind in Hungary. Don’t miss the chance to peek into the rooms of researchers and the auditoriums located within the premises.

Did you know that the King St. Stephen Museum houses the Archaeological exhibition, which takes visitors on an incredible journey from the Neolithic era to the end of the Turkish subjection in Fejér County?

Address: Fő u. 6, Székesfehérvár

How to get there: The museum is centrally located and can be easily reached by foot, taxi, or public transportation from any part of the city.

Ticket price: Check the official website for current prices and opening hours.

In the centre of Szekesfehervar, lies the Medieval Ruin Garden, a must-visit destination for history enthusiasts. This interesting site was once the coronation church of Hungarian Kings, where a staggering 38 kings were crowned during the Middle Ages. Today, visitors can wander through the remnants of this ancient church, marveling at its ornate sarcophagus of St. Stephen and the remarkable wall-painting by Vilmos Aba-Novák, depicting the Holy Right and the Holy Crown.

Fun Fact: Did you know that the archaeological excavations at the Medieval Ruin Garden began in 1862 and are still ongoing today?

Address: Koronázó tér 1, Székesfehérvár

How to Get There: The garden is within walking distance from the city centre and easily accessible by public transportation.

Ticket Price: Check the official website for current prices and opening hours.

Are you ready for an exciting journey back in time? Let me take you to the beautiful Saint Stephen Basilica, located in Székesfehérvár, Hungary. This magnificent church, first mentioned in 1031, was not only the coronation church of the Hungarian Kings but also a burial ground for 14 Hungarian kings and numerous royal family members.

As you step inside, be prepared to be amazed by the highly ornate sarcophagus of St. Stephen, the founder of the Hungarian state. This sacred place also holds the incredible wall-painting of Vilmos Aba-Novák, depicting the Holy Right and the Holy Crown. Can you imagine the grandeur and significance of this site?

Address: Arany János u. 9

How to get there: The Saint Stephen Basilica is centrally located and easily accessible

Ticket Price: Check the official website for current prices and opening hours.

As a resting point, right before lunch, let’s dive into a little bit of history, nature, and typical Hungarian weirdness. History and nature beautifully intertwine at Királyok parkja, also known as Park of the Hungarian Kings. This interesting park, located at Horog utca 12, captures the essence of Hungarian royalty and offers a unique experience for visitors.

To reach Királyok parkja, you have to walk away from the city centre, hidden between Kelemen Béla út and the fishing lakes. As you stroll through this picturesque area, you’ll encounter a remarkable statue group that was erected on August 20, 1988.

Fun Fact: The statues in Királyok parkja pay tribute to the kings buried in Székesfehérvár and include inscriptions with their names and years of reign. These sculptures were set up to commemorate the 950th anniversary of Saint Stephen’s death.

Address: Horog utca 12

After soaking up the history and beauty of Székesfehérvar, your stomach might be calling for a bit of attention. Fear not, for the city centre, brimming with Hungarian charm, is the perfect place to sate your hunger. The vibrant and lively Fő tér, or Main Square, offers a plethora of eateries serving up local and international cuisines. The cobblestone streets and quaint building facades add a certain charm to your dining experience. It’s a delightful spot to enjoy a meal, whilst watching the world go by.

Now, it’s finally time for the highlight of the day – exploring Szekesfehervar’s hidden gems. As a city with deep historical roots, there are plenty of attractions to explore.

We only include one activity in the afternoon, because you should really take your time for this one!

After exploring Bory Castle, we suggest you to have a relaxing afternoon and evening, further exploring the city centre and restaurants in the city.

Bory Castle, situated in the charming city of Szekesfehervar, Hungary, is a truly extraordinary architectural masterpiece that defies convention and captures the imagination. This eccentric castle, meticulously crafted by the visionary Hungarian artist, Jenő Bory, over the course of four decades, stands as a testament to his unwavering dedication and artistic prowess.

Enveloped by lush and vibrant gardens, the castle invites visitors into a world of enchantment and wonder. Its imposing structure showcases a harmonious fusion of architectural styles, seamlessly blending elements of Romanesque grandeur, Gothic allure, and Renaissance elegance. Every intricate detail, from the ornate carvings to the majestic towers, tells a story of passion and creativity.

As you wander through the castle’s sprawling grounds, you’ll discover hidden alcoves, secret passageways, and captivating vistas that transport you to a bygone era. The interplay of light and shadow, combined with the symphony of colors, creates an atmosphere that is both ethereal and awe-inspiring. Amidst the tranquil beauty that surrounds you, you can’t help but be captivated by the whimsical charm and timeless allure of Bory Castle.

Whether you’re a history enthusiast, an art lover, or simply seeking a magical escape, a visit to Bory Castle promises an unforgettable experience. Immerse yourself in the rich tapestry of history, marvel at the architectural marvels, and let your imagination roam free in this extraordinary haven of creativity and beauty.

Fun fact: Bory Castle was constructed entirely by hand, using simple tools, and the artist’s visionary imagination.

Address: Bory Castle, Alkotmány Street 1, Szekesfehervar, Hungary.

How to get there: You can reach Bory Castle by car or public transport. From Budapest, take a train or bus to Szekesfehervar, and then it’s a short taxi ride to the castle.

Want to know more about Bory Castle? Read our in-depth guide to this attraction!

So, a visit to the National Theatre is definitely an option, if you like to experience one of the grand shows. Chances are that you won’t understand a word of it, just like us.

If you do speak Hungarian, and you like to experience a show, check out the calendar for the National Theatre.

Otherwise, be just like us and keep your exploration to the outside of the building, which is also very nice, but it won’t take hours to see.

Address: Theatre, Fói krt. 17, Székesfehérvár, Hungary

There’s nothing quite like a serene evening stroll by Székesfehérvár’s City Lake, also known as the “Csónakázó-tó”. This tranquil spot in the heart of the city is an oasis of calm as the sun sets. Watch the ducks glide gently across the water, soak in the beautiful sight of the setting sun casting a warm glow over the landscape, and let the stress of the day melt away. If you’re feeling particularly adventurous, hop on a pedal boat for a leisurely ride around the lake. It’s the perfect way to round off your day!

Good to know, the lake is quite urban. It has a Best Western Hotel and there’s a restaurant as well.

Address: Csónakázó-tó, Székesfehérvár, Hungary

Székesfehérvár, a historic gem nestled in the heart of Hungary, is just a stone’s throw away from Budapest. Depending on your preference, there are several means of transport to get you there.

One of the most common ways to get to Szekesfehervar is by train. The city has a well-developed railway network, and there are regular trains from major cities like Budapest. The journey takes approximately one hour from Budapest, making it a convenient option for day-trippers. The train station in Szekesfehervar is centrally located, making it easy to explore the city once you arrive.

By Air: Budapest Ferenc Liszt International Airport is the closest airport to Szekesfehervar. From the airport, you can rent a car or take a taxi to Szekesfehervar, which is approximately a 1-hour drive.

By Train: The Hungarian State Railways (MÁV) offers excellent service between Budapest and Szekesfehervar. The journey typically takes about an hour and a half, providing you with a scenic window into the enchanting Hungarian countryside. Trains depart from Budapest’s Deli station regularly throughout the day.

By Car: If you prefer the freedom and flexibility of your own vehicle, Szekesfehervar is conveniently located along the M7 motorway. The drive from Budapest to Szekesfehervar is approximately 65 km and can easily be done in less than an hour.

By Coach: Several coach services, like Volánbusz, provide affordable and comfortable transportation from Budapest to Szekesfehervar. The journey can take up to two hours, depending on traffic.

When visiting Szekesfehervar, Hungary, it’s important to find the perfect place to stay that suits your needs and preferences. Luckily, Szekesfehervar offers a variety of accommodation options to choose from, ensuring that there is something for every traveler.

If you’re looking for a unique experience, consider staying in one of the boutique hotels in Szekesfehervar.

Overall, Szekesfehervar offers a range of accommodation options to cater to different tastes and budgets.
